how do you respectfully handle missionaries like this without exploding at them or getting upset with them for weeks on end?

 
 Remember, they chose to interrupt your private life for their own desires/needs. It's your choice to allow them to take your time, or not. "I'm not interested" *close door* is entirely polite. Likewise with phone solicitation. Thank you, not interested, goodbye (even though they are still jabbering). (EP said a similar thing)
 
 As to dwelling on negative events for weeks on end, try mental conditioning. It's easier than it sounds. Just remember your mind is your body, it can be easily trained, actually it's designed to be trained. Force yourself to not think of what it is that's bugging you. And again, and again. Continue to push it from your thoughts (what you think about in it's place is irrelevant, it can be anything/nothing, doesn't have to be "happy thoughts", that's unecessary).
 
 Once you do this for a while, you'll find it's second-nature, a habit, to be able to re-focus your mind off a particular topic. And no, you won't "forget" it, it just won't occupy your mind as much. 
 
 -Mach

Here's some suggestions on how to handle "missionaries."
 
 If you get a phone call from a "christian" proselytizer (or any other annoying sales call), as soon as you realize the nature of the call, tell them that you would like to hear what they have to say but that there is someone at the door. Put the phone down and go on about your business. Check on them in a few minutes. If they are so stupid as to still be there, tell them to hang on, you're still dealing with the delivery. Put the phone down again. Repeat as necessary.
 
 When they come to your door, smile and tell them, "No thank you. I'm a Christian." Slowly close the door and then throw the bolt with as much force as possible. I say to "slowly close the door" so that you might have the pleasure of observing their fish out of water expressions. Also, it they have heard the answer before, you are more likely to see them flip the rod and can throw open the door and get in their face - I'm better than 230 lbs at 6'5" and it works for me.
 
 Another possibility is to invite them in and seat at the kitchen table and then offer them a cup of coffee. When they decline, berate their unwillingness to have a friendly cup of coffee with you and tell them to get out. Be sure that they are from a cult that doesn't drink coffee. A friend of mine did this with missionaries from one cult. They headed for the door when he started his hissy fit.
 
 Just some ideas.
 
 Edit: By the way, Ladywolf. It is totally irrelevant whether you are or are not a christian. The point is that you respond to the annoying dweebs that you are and shut the door (and throw the bolt). It adds to a bad day for the dweebs. Don't get mad - get even.

 15 But when He who had set me apart, even from my mother's womb, called me through His grace, was pleased 16to reveal His son in me ...
 
 From v. 16, 'to reveal His son in me', Spong claims: This was not a physical body recalled from the grave. What was the nature of a theophany? Was it really 'physical'? What was the means of hearing God's voice speak? Was it audible to any ear? Was it capable of being recorded or objectified?

A logician would also note that Spong commits the fallacy of false alternatives, because he overlooks the possibility that seeing could be both physical and supra-physical, rather that either/or. We thought that it was strange that Spong should ignore this point. However, we decided to check a Greek NT82 to see if Spong had at least analysed the word correctly in this passage. But we could not find òphthè in the passage. To give Spong a second shot, we checked a NT Greek Interlinear. The word was not there either. Instead, the Greek word for 'reveal' in Gal. 1:16 is actually apokalupsai, not òphthè! Apokalupsai is often used in the NT in an objective sense.83

 I assume you took this from Luke 23:13-14. The date of this gospel (circa 90 CE) as well as its contents suggest that the author was not an eyewitness to the events he describes. Indeed, he tells us in his prologue that he compiled his gospel from the writings of others. However, the fact that Luke's genealogy of Jesus conflicts with that given to us by Matthew should tell you something. They can't both be correct. Apologists have attempted to get around this by claiming that, whereas Matthew's genealogy of Jesus runs through Joseph, Luke's genealogy of Jesus runs through Mary. This, despite the fact that Luke's account mentions Jesus' father Joseph, but not Mary. Luke traces Jesus' genealogy through Joseph. 
 
 
There's simply no credible foundation for that hypothesis - that his disciples engineered all that.

 
 And what is your evidence to the contrary, EZ? The conflicting accounts given to us by non-eyewitness followers of the Jesus cult written decades after the fact? I thus introduce you to the idea of probability based upon historical study. You're not going to like this, but I hope that you'll at least consider it. Jesus was executed by the Romans (not the Jews) by virtue of the likelihood that the Romans considered Jesus to be both a troublemaker (temple incident on the eve of Passover) and seditionist ("King of the Jews"). A king was expected to liberate his people from foreign occupation. Am I going too fast for you? 
 
 Thus, Pilate probably ordered one of his officers to get rid of Jesus in an expedient manner. There would have been no trial, given that Jesus was considered to be a nobody, lacking power, influence, or wealth. Thus, death by crucifixion. Following this, Jesus' body was probably thrown into a garbage dump, to be consumed by birds and dogs. This was part of the punishment inflicted by the Romans, denying the body a proper burial. Thus, in all probability, no tomb. Thus, no bodily resurrection of Jesus from a tomb. Thus, no bodily ascension of Jesus into the sky toward heaven.
 
 In all probability, Jesus's followers attempted to make sense of all this, and wove a story around it as justification for Jesus' untimely and humiliating death. And you've obviously bought into it.

 Those who agitate for science teachers to put 'theory, not fact' warning labels on certain topics do not, as a rule, understand what a scientific theory actually is. Virtually everything that is taught as the working foundation of science is actually theory: atomic structure, the model of the solar system, the nature of electromagnetic radiation - all theories. However, they are all backed up by such mountains of experimental and observational evidence, and are so powerful in their predictive capabilities, that to keep warning students 'Remember - this is theory!' would be a pointless distraction. The theory of evolution rests on an equally impressive bedrock of evidence, and is an equally powerful predictive tool. Why should it be singled out among scientific theories as the one to carry a health warning?
